reviewText: A well-made, well acted drama about the ministry of this remarkable 20th century doctor who devoted his adult life to caring for the poor in Naples, Italy. This made-for-TV Italian film portrays very vividly Moscati giving free medical care and even giving his own money to his patients for additional medication and/or food. Not shown in the film is that he was known during his 25-year medical career not only to pray often & fervently for the healing of his patients but also for the strength and faith to find ways to help those with severe medical problems.Moscati's fondness for the princess Elena (played by the lovely Casia Smutniak) makes for an entertaining subplot, but is fictitious. All in all I found this film to be inspiring biopic about this selfless humanist.
Title: N/A

reviewText: If you are Italian, especially Southern Italian, it is important that you see this priceless little film on one of the most compassionate human beings that ever lived. Giuseppe Moscati was an actual doctor who lived in Napoli at the turn of the last century. He ministered to the poor and spent his own savings to alleviate their sufferings. Even non-Catholics will love the charm of this film and its compassionate hero.

reviewText: What a wonderful movie about a Saint who in my opinion was a Saint before they even canonized him. Saint Giuseppe's life is so inspiring and it makes us want to strive to be the best we can be in our own lives. :)

reviewText: This is a wonderful story of St Giuseppe Moscati! I promise you, you will fall in love with this saint and will be happy you saw this movie! Although it does not tell about all the spiritual things this saint did, it does show in a touching way the "Saint in the man" and you will be moved by him and his life. The film is in Italian, but my children (9 & 10)watched the movie without reading the subtitle as it is so intriguing and draws you in! It has become one of our favorite movies and he is one of our favorite saints!
summary: You Will Love This Saint and His Story
Title: N/A

reviewText: We all have, or at least have had, doctors we trust and even love.  Too often, however, many of us have complaints about doctors' priorities, quality time spent with us, attitudes, and even competence.  Alongside the Hippocratic Oath should be placed a model doctor, indeed, a saint according to the Roman Catholic Church, Giuseppe Frascati.  The film Giusepe Frascati: Doctor to the Poor presents viewers with a strong sense of this selfless physician's life among those who crave his services.  Despite keen opposition from mercenary, exclusive, or negligent fellow doctors and administrators, Giuseppe Frascati goes quietly but forcefully about his job of healing patients on every social level.  The sick poor feel free to enter his house and state their needs.  Youngsters hardened and criminal on the streets of Naples cling to him, trust him, love him.  Dr. Frascati gives himself tirelessly to his benevolent tasks, often endangering his own health, keeling over from exhaustion, depriving himself of sleep, pleasures, and, on one occasion, furniture, in order to purchase supplies and conduct procedures.  Whether or not we're talking about formal canonization, one must say that this accurate depiction of a saintly doctor inspires and often moves viewers to tears.  Doctors, nurses, LPN's and laypersons alike may draw inspiration from this moving yet unsentimental treatment of the life of an exceptional person.
Title: N/A
